content.description:
Long corner system to the right of Smoked Salmon.The bottom is dirty and unlikely to ever be clean. Climb Swipe Right to climb the good part. Gear to 4".



Approach as for Dinosaur Killer and Swipe Right up the fixed rope right above the East Wall trail sign


Gear to 4"

The sport line immediately right of Cooks Crack. Reachy face climbing. Recommend clipping the first bolt of Feeding the Family and traversing left into Bag'O Beans. Direct start is a tad run out and nearly impossible for those of a shorter stature.



Trail to the east wall

bolts.

climbs.name: Beautiful Arete
climbs.fa: Cleaned and TR'ed Leroy Froese c. 1999. Rescrubbed, bolted & led D Brayshaw, T de Monye April 2010

content.description:
Begin up an offset finger crack notable for a huge xenolith pocket off to the left. Where the crack thins, step right to the arete. Climb on the left side of the arete up compact but featured rock past three bolts, then more directly on the arete as it becomes more broken, placing small wires and thin cams in horizontal breaks. Originally cleaned in the late 1990s as a toprope, but never led, and subsequently became overgrown. Now established as a lead climb. This route is located along the East Wall Trail about 40m to the right (east) of the Shark Tooth Flake area. Look for the obvious clean arete.

30m rappel from ring bolts on the top ledge. Ignore the old weathered slings wrapped around the fir tree on the ledge. 3 bolts and 3 or 4 pieces of gear to 1" (small wires up to blue TCU size)

climbs.name: Beaver Buzz
climbs.fa: D. Brayshaw A. Palmer J. Valecko, January 2019

content.description:
Start up a ramp and move right to the arete where there is a good gear placement in a flake. Above, climb past three bolts, climbing mostly on the right side of the arete. Generally cruiser climbing with one tricky move (high step or use holds way out right) at the second bolt.

In case you're wondering what Beaver Buzz is...


The right arete of the small blunt buttress on the trail up to Mechanical Advantage, and just left of the jungle scramble that leads to the top of Shark Tooth Flake.
3 bolts, one finger sized cam. Rap rings to descend.

This is the 4th crack from left which climbs up through a series of blocks. 5.8 start to 5.6 moves to a rap ring

Kindergarten corner lies slightly east of Shark Tooth Flake and Beautiful Arete. Follow the left wall uphill just past the maple tree.
Cams to 2.5"

Recleaned route at left end of the Smoked Salmon/Babolious crag. Climb face to left of left-leaning seam. Left hand on arete, right hand in seam, bear hug moves in a few places.

Immediately right of the chimney and left of Smoked Salmon
Two bolts, small nuts, #2 camalot. Rap anchor on top.

The left facing corner crack right of Sharktooth Flake and The Matrix. Start easily up the corner. Climb a wide section then layback where the crack thins down. At the top, which is quite dirty, move out of the crack via faceholds on the right wall.

Gear to 3"
Rap from slings and rap rings around the big tree up and right of the topout.

Easy obvious corner crack. A great first trad lead with an abundance of gear options. At the anchor head right on 2 bolts for a worthwhile 5.8 hanging traverse. Takes you to the anchor of Given'er the Beans and Skinny Fingers.


single rack.
Left of Skinny Fingers. Small to .75 C4

climbs.name: Dead Hazel
climbs.fa: Jack Pals, D and W Morris, April 1999

content.description:
The bush-filled, overgrown corner with a couple large loose blocks immediately right of Beautiful Arete on the East Wall trail. 
  
 It is hard to imagine that this was once a clean route. In its present state it illustrates how quickly nature reclaims old routes!

Immediately right of Beautiful Arete, leading to the same ledge.
Lawnmower, pet goat, bush cutters, gardening gloves and/or thick skin appear helpful

Start up a blank dihedral with a thin crack on the right wall. Big stems past a bolt (crux) eventually lead to a transfer to the left arete. Above, move right across the wall past a second bolt to gain a hanging slab. Turn the corner past a third bolt to gain the beautiful right-facing corner crack which is followed to the top belay ledge, gradually widening from fingers to offwidth. Descend by rappel.

A couple of thin cracks continue above the ledge and possibly top out but look quite challenging and have not yet been cleaned. 



Just left of Babolious. From 10 m right of the the base of Smoked Salmon, pull up a fixed rope to access a belay ledge (room for about 4 people) at the base of Babolious and DK.

Three bolts, and gear consisting of cams from fingers to OW size.

The arete at the left edge of Kindergarten Wall. Climb a bolted wide flake crack past 3 bolts to gain the arete. Continue up the arete to a cruxy bulge, joining into The First Degree at the last bolt.

Arete at left edge of K-Wall. Also one arete right of Beautiful Arete.
Eight or nine bolts.

Fun sport line with a tricky to read crux. Left of Cooks Corner.


bolts.

On Kindergarten Wall. Climb the first cracks of Red Dutch until level with the first rap hanger station on that route. Move left out a horizontal finger crack to a large pocket, then climb face and a shallow hanging corner past 5 bolts to the ledge. The left arete is generally avoided except for a short section near the fifth bolt.

Between Red Dawn and the arete on the left side of Kindergarten Cliff. Rappel from the rap ring station as for Red Dawn. 60m rope fine for rappel.
Gear to 2" for the lower cracks, plus 5 bolts.

Fantastic splitter crack that curves gently under a large roof. As the name would infer, round up as many purples as you can find. Two will do if you're conscientious, three were used on the FA, and one new trad climber was seen reasonably placing five.



In the obvious corner above / after the ladder on the east wall trail.

Doubles .3 to .75

The layback with a midway anchor. Single rack with an emphasis on .4/.5 cams. 

Take the 5 bolt extension past the anchor at 12a or so. Pop an optional .75 cam in the under cling. A perplexing yet excellent line. Varied.


SIngle rack/bolts.

Slab climb past a bolt to a large ledge. Make a strenuous roof pull to a nice finger crack(physical crux). Continue to a right-leaning crack and make a balancey move over the arete (technical crux). Slab climb past three bolts to the anchor



Right of “Crack of Dawn”, Left of “Wildcat”

Small cams up to .75, 8 draws.

Start at the base of the corner and move left onto the face. Make thin, hard face moves past three bolts, using pockets and thin edges. A couple meters above the last bolt reach left to join 'Shark Tooth Flake' directly at a large horizontal jug and climb it easily to the top. 
  
 Originally graded 5.13a, Marc later suggested a downgrade to 12d. But the crux highstep is extremely bouldery and remains unrepeated. Who knows?

Immediately right of Shark Tooth Flake.
Three bolts and a peice of gear or two for the finish.

Pitch 1: 5.10b, 7 bolts, gear (three cams, finger to #3 Camalot size), 35 m. Climb a short corner and face past a bolt to ledges. Traverse a sloping ramp above ledges to a couple slab moves (5 bolts) to gain a hanging right facing corner and gear protected climbing. Layback up this (fingers to fist) to a tricky mantle. Squirm past a giant Doug Fir (one more bolt) to anchors. Follow a trail up and left to a handline leading to the next ledge. Pitch 2: 5.8, 6 bolts, 30 m Climb a pocketed slab up from the belay and curve left. All bolt protected. Small stance belay below a giant curving flake. Pitch 3: 5.9, all gear protected (gear to 3", medium cams to #3 camalot and some small/med wire nuts), 25 m The flake directly above the belay is solid but the flake above that is thin and hollow-sounding. So avoid it by underclinging left from the belay around the arete and then climb past a block and up thin finger cracks to the top of the buttress. Pitch 2 and 3 might be linkable but watch for rope drag. The direct flake on p3 has been top roped gingerly at 5.10 but is probably not a good choice for a gear lead. Pitch 4 is only worth doing if going on to Change Room or Turbulence above. Scramble back from the belay and climb a 2-bolt face (one hard slabby boulder move, then easy cruising) 10m , 2 bolts. Ends right at the base of the Change Room. Approach: from the East Wall trail, about halfway between Wildcat and Shark Tooth Flake. From the logs on the trail look left to see a scramble trail heading uphill. Follow this to a large boulder and short step with a fixed handline. Climb starts just above.

All belays are fixed for rappel. You can get down P1 with a 60 m rope. When rapping P3, there is a fixed permadraw between P3 and the direct flake - clip both ropes to this on the way down so that the flake doesn't eat your rope when you pull the rap ropes! Gear from small wire nuts to #3 Camalot. About 10 draws should be sufficient for pro; use more, and more long draws if linking p2 and p3

Climb a straight-in crack that becomes a layback to a ledge with a tree. Pull over a roof and gain a flake crack above. From the top of the flake move past a bolt to a thin crack. From the top of the thin crack, face moves and ledges past another bolt lead to the belay ledge and a chain anchor.

Left of and facing Beautiful Arete.
Gear to 3", several finger sized cams useful. Chain station on top.

Climb the bottom of 'Fresh Outta' until you can escape left onto the face to a cool jug pocket + bolt line. Climb up around the top-side edge of the roof on sparse slab features



In the obvious corner above / after the ladder on the east wall trail.

1 x .5 and 8 bolts

Climb past the old rap anchors up the crack to ledge. The crux is an awkward offwidth section near the top.

This is the left most crack in Kindergarten Corner which is reached by following the trail east just past Shark Tooth Flake
cams to 2.5"

Reachy face moves over a small roof, past a bolt to a left facing corner (crux), then easier climbing to the chains.

Right of Shark Tooth & Blue Pill
Single rack. #4 useful

Climb easily up the wide crack forming the left side of the detached flake until standing on the sharp pointy tip. Protect the next moves well to avoid impalement on the sharp flake if you muff the crux! 
  
 Climb the finger crack above the sharktooth, cruxy at first then widening and easing off with some footholds out on the face to the right and a small flake roof. End on a ledge with a pair of rap hangers.

Follow the trail to the base of the crag and head east (right) along the base of the wall for 5 minutes or so to an obvious detached sharp-tipped flake sitting against the cliff.
Finger to hand size pro with 1 or 2 larger pieces for the flake.

Start up the finger crack in the steepening groove then get your slab on as it spits you out into 'ripple' features on the face. A short thin hanging corner and a traverse right to large block lead to the bolted belay. A good varied pitch!

On the way to the East Wall, where the trail turns a sharp corner after leaving the swamp.
a few draws and small TCU's. Thin wires or #00 TCU works for the hanging corner....

The climb breaks down into three sections with ledges between. You could do it in two or even three pitches if you want, or link it all in one.
 
 The first 10 m starts up pockets off a stone patio to a thin seam. Get some finger size gear in (blue or grey TCU or small nut) before the first bolt, then balancy moves past 2 bolts (crux of the whole route) and then easier climbing (more wires or small cams) to the first big ledge.

 The next 20 m is an enjoyable 5.6 corner crack. Lots of good stemming and hand jamming. Several 1" to 2" cams and a few wire nuts. This gets you to the second ledge and a bolted belay.

 For the final 20 m the corner ends and the crack turns into a seam with pods, following an eroded dyke, that gradually transitions back into a stemming corner. Climb the seam (moves to 5.9 but not sustained) until it lays back and the corner ends. Move right up a slab to a roof with two cracks. Pull the roof to a big ledge. 3 bolts and gear (mostly cams) from fingers to fists for the pods. Save a #2 or #3 Camalot for the final roof crack.

 Two raps down, 20 m to ledge then 30 m to ground. Both stations have rings and chains.

From the East Wall trail, hike up past Red Dawn and Bin Leadin, then traverse across to the base. Look for a stone patio made from trundled flakes and start from that.
Full rack from #1 rock to # 3 and/or #4 Camalot (#4 may not be needed). Bring triple of the hand size (#1 Camalot or equivalents)

This new variation is a link up of lower Dinosaur Killer with upper Babolious, avoiding the junky lower section of Babolious in favor of some rope drag. Climb the first 20 m or so of Dinosaur Killer and at the top of the finger crack dihedral, step right onto a ledge of the arete. Shuffle right again and down a bit to step into the groove of Babolious. Climb up the groove until it ends at a layback. Blue collar laybacking for a few cruxy moves up a trough/crack that changes size erratically until you get a good foothold and it eases off. Continue more easily up a blocky groove to the upper crux, weird laybacking through a bulge. Finish up a 4" offwidth to the rap anchor on a ledge. 



Just right of Dinosaur Killer. See TOPO


7 bolts and gear, mostly cams from finger sized to 4". Bringing both a #3 and #4 Camalot is recommended. Not many good or solid nut placements.

YOU NEED AN 80M ROPE TO RAP OR LOWER FROM THE TOP ANCHOR TO THE BASE. A 70M WILL NOT MAKE IT FROM THE TOP ANCHOR. To get down with a shorter rope, rap to the Dinosaur Killer anchor and then rap from there back to the base.

Climb a ramp to below a bolt and mantle onto a ledge. Climb a thin crack off the ledge with a couple of finger pods and good foot edges to a bulge. Laybacking and blind gear placements lead over the bulge to a good rest and easier low-angle climbing up a hand crack to the top.

The crack is not a nice splitter to start; it's a seam that is mostly knifeblade wide with a variety of wider pods. Halfway up, it widens to fingers then thin hands. Gear can be tricky to place at the bottom. The first ascent used a #1 stopper, #1 Peenut, mid-sized RP, orange TCU and #1 camalot, but other things might work too.

The tiny nuts are both placed above a ledge and there is ledge-fall potential if they pull as you climb by them. Because the climb is so close to Beaver Buzz and it's easy to TR from that route's anchor, it didn't seem right to use more bolts for pro here near the thin seam as anyone uncertain about the gear can easily check out the climb on TR instead.

Just left of Beaver Buzz and climbs to the same anchor, on the small buttress on the right halfway up the Mechanical Advantage approach trail. .
One bolt and #1 stopper, #1 Peenut, mid-sized RP, orange or yellow TCU and #1 camalot. Rap rings on top.

Start off a freestanding boulder, clip a bolt, and mantle to a ledge. Climb up zigzag ramps, then make several more mantles past a variety of ledges, pockets and edges to a final, cruxy mantle (or fruitless beached whale belly-flop) onto the final slab at the anchor.

Just left of Tension Crack, and right of the handline leading up to the start of Mechanical Advantage.
Six bolts. Anchor bolts. Rap from Beaver Buzz/Tension Crack to get down.

Climb over the low roof left of Red Pill and then straight up the face on potato chip edges. Move right at the top to the Red Pill anchor

Between Blue Pill and Red Pill. It's about 5 m left of Red Pill, and around the arete to the right of Blue Pill.
7 bolts.

climbs.name: Wildcat
climbs.fa: D Brayshaw S Neufeld June 16, 2011. second pitch originally done as a finish to Wayback Layback by Crawshaw and Howden crew circa 1994

content.description:
Layback the wide flake crack to a pinnacle. Move right past the first bolt (tricky boulder move, probably harder than 5.8 but right at the bolt) on pockets and edge to a right facing flake. Up this and the curving crack above to ledge. Pull flake through the overhang then climb featured slab past more bolts to the station, which is just above the belay tree for Wayback Layback, Crack of Dawn and Sliver and can be used to set a TR on these climbs. Named after a bobcat that was prowling around the base. From the bolted belay, a second pitch (30m, ~5.7) continues up the low angle stepped arete to the ledge below Bigfoot. Three bolts plus several pieces of finger sized gear. When walking the trail east to Sharktooth Flake etc. from the Sleeping Princess area this climb is obvious on the left. scramble up a short trail to the base. From the belay atop the first pitch, rappel (don't lower, see note) or climb the second pitch and then walk off. Note you can rappel from the first station with a 60m rope but to lower you need a 70m. If lowering with a 60m you can only get to the pinnacle 5m off the ground and may have to downclimb from there. The second pitch anchor also has a rappel chain. It is exactly 60m from the upper anchor to the base, but it's hard to climb the combined route in one linked pitch with a 60m rope because with all the pro placed the line of the climb angled and so more like 70m than 60m. **Don't let your belayer drop you by running the end of the rope through their device while lowering with a 60m.*** First pitch: Four bolts and three or four cams 1/2" to 2". Rappel anchors on top (rap rings).
Second pitch: three bolts and several finger-sized nuts or cams. Bolted anchor on top.
These are generally one and two pitch climbs found scattered along the trail from From the Ground Up area to the East Wall.
